text: I'd like to talk a little bit about a very useful technique in the vipassana tradition, which is called labeling. As I mentioned, the basic principle in vipassana is to train, to be able to maintain specific awareness with respect to the components of one's experience, moment by moment. Like the proverbial pie, our experience can be cut up a lot of different ways, and you can cut it into six pieces, but then each one of those pieces can be cut into sub-pieces, and the pieces, sub-pieces can be more finely cut, because there are components, sub-components, sub-sub-components in every experience. For example, if a person is having what in the English language is referred to as an emotion, a negative emotion, let's say like fear or anger or irritation, that experience has basically two components. One is that there are ideas, a sequence of ideas erupt in the mind, and at the same time a sequence of sensations erupt in the body. So the first level of cutting that experience or being aware of components would be to be able to keep track what part of the experience is ideas, what part of the experience is body sensations. So that would be keeping track of the components. But if you take a particular component, for example the body sensations, those body sensations will be welling up in different parts of the body. So to be aware of the locations as they change moment by moment would be to be aware of sub-components of that experience. The body sensation is made up of a welling up in the knee and then a welling up in the chest and then a welling up over the whole body and then maybe a welling up that goes to three or four places and then a welling up that goes into the face, for example. So to know at any given moment the body sensation involves face, chest, knee, whole body, is to know the sub-components. To be aware that each welling up itself involves smaller fluctuations, each wave is made of sub-waves, etc. To be able to trace that would be to know the sub-sub-components. Likewise with the thought, to be able to be distinctly aware of each burst of thoughts, to know if thought is a component, then each burst is a sub-component and each burst itself may speed up or slow down, may accelerate or decelerate. To know those rates of acceleration and deceleration would be to know the sub-sub-components. Having any motion is a rather large piece of experience. When the resistance breaks up completely, then that pain turns into effortless flowing energy. But the resistance, this is a sort of subtle point, but the resistance may be in the process of breaking up, but it hasn't broken up completely, well the pain will still be rather solid. It may not bother you so much, okay, but it's still going to be really solid. But when that level of resistance, resistance breaks up completely, then there's nothing to impede the flow of the pain anymore and it breaks up into effortless expansion and contraction. But the point is that we're not trying to get the pain to go away. We're trying to observe the pain long enough so that the underlying resistance goes away and that can only happen as an act of nature. We can't make that happen. When the underlying resistance goes away, that's a permanent change. Pains come and go, okay, but the purification of consciousness is permanent. So you're not trying to make that sensation assume a certain form. You're trying to perfuse that sensation with continuous mindfulness and equanimity. Somewhere along the line as you're doing that, the underlying resistance will crack. And if it cracks enough, at a deep enough level, the pain itself will become fluid. But you should never have that as the goal because that will just delay that whole process. So you can't sit there and say, I want to sit here until this breaks up or goes away because that will just make it stay and stay and stay and stay. You just sit there. I'll tell you the quickest way to break up pain in your body. That's the good news. I can tell you exactly the fastest way in nature to make that pain go away. You know, the shortest distance between two lines is called a geodesic. In flat space, it's a straight line. On the surface of the earth, it would be along a great circle. But in different kinds of spaces, whatever constitutes the shortest path between two points is called the geodesic of that space. We live in the Euclidean flat space, so usually for us, it's a straight line. Any other path than a straight line is longer. It takes you longer to get there than the straight line. So the good news is I can tell you what the straight line is in the experience space. The quickest way to break up pain in your body. That's the good news. Here's the bad news. The bad news is the quickest way to break up pain in your body is be willing that the pain never go away. Really. To reach that point where you're willing to be there infinitely with it. At that time, that will break up the pain most quickly. So it's like one of God's jokes. Very wry sense of humor, don't you think? It seems to me any specific sensation I experience in the larger field, and when one is working with a label, say for example, label is eyebrow. If I'm using that label and I'm focusing all of my attention just on eyebrow, I potentially lose that larger field. It almost is a constriction rather than just an awareness. If you find that the larger field is what pulls you most naturally, which is then basically it's your whole body, then just keep labeling whole body, whole body, whole body. But if you find that you are pulled at some time towards something that pulls you in, then let that happen and just label and be intensely aware of that. And then go back to that sense of the larger field. Okay, then remember the labels are only an approximation. So you can use the labels for the small parts, but your awareness can still be aware of the larger picture, you might say. And there's nothing wrong with the awareness being confined to small areas, as long as there's mindfulness and equanimity as that's happening. Okay, yes? My teaching has been to stay away from labels because they're falsifications of experience. I think what you're saying is that the label is not supposed to be in any way equal to the experience. Is it useful, I guess what I find useful to think of it as being like a flashlight, to say that I'm pointing to what I'm trying to be aware of? Exactly correct. Think of the label as a flashlight. And you don't, okay there, see it? You can see there. Okay, now you can see there. Now you can see there. That's exactly what it's like. That's actually a good metaphor. I'm going to remember that and use it. It's like shining a flashlight, so everything becomes very bright in that place. It's the brightness that we're trying to develop, not figuring out a description of what's going on. And in fact, even though I describe this, and all vipassana teachers describe vipassana as observing, in fact it's not observing. That's a completely misleading way to describe vipassana. And yet every vipassana teacher does it. Why? Because it's a simple way to describe it, but really we're not observing. What we're doing is we are turning up the brightness of the flashlight. We're actually turning on the brightness in all the different parts of our experience. We're not observing experience. We're increasing, it's like on your TV screen, okay, you know you have different brightness. What we're actually doing is infusing brightness into the six senses. We're not observing the six senses. So your metaphor of a flashlight is quite good actually. I could see the brightness, but I don't see the exclusion of the vision. Yes, I understand. I'll get into it for just a second, and later on I'll get into it in more detail. The reason that the word observing is misleading, and yet we all use it, is that observing implies that there's a meditator over here observing the sensations over here. And actually that's not really what vipassana ends up being. Although at the beginning it is going to be that. At the beginning, just like to build a building, you have to put up a scaffolding, and then you're able to build the building and the scaffolding comes down. In order to learn these techniques you have to create what I call a meditating ego, which is a sense of a self running a meditation procedure. But once you've learned that procedure, you have to let that scaffolding come down. The building that you're building is mindfulness. It's not a mindful person. It is the quality of mindfulness. So at the beginning, whenever something wells up, you make a mental label and you let your awareness soak into that object. When you make that mental label, one of the reasons that some people don't like you to do the label is that reinforces the sense of a self over here observing it over there. At some point you can drop that labeling. And what you're really doing is infusing the qualities of brightness and relaxation into each phenomenon. Well, a time comes when the brightness and relaxation becomes so habitual that you don't need a meditating self in order to run that program. It's just there. Does that make sense that that could happen? Like when you drive the car. When you first learned how to drive the car, you had to think about every single aspect of driving the car. It's not reflective in the sense that it doesn't need to reflect a sense of self. Okay. Right now, do you feel self-conscious a little bit? Yes, right. If you investigate carefully, you'll find that some of that self-consciousness is body sensation. And some of that self-consciousness is ideas. Right now everybody's looking at me and I don't know much about this and they all know a lot about this. And I don't know if the teacher is going to praise me or make me feel like a jerk. Okay. These are ideas. And you have an image of yourself here at this retreat. Those are ideas. And then there are body sensations. So at this time, your sense of self is being brought to you by certain ideas and certain body sensations. Underneath those are subliminal ideas and subliminal body sensations. And underneath those are subconscious ideas and subconscious body sensations. When the brightness and the relaxation starts to perfuse those ideas and those body sensations that right now are giving you that sense of self, then you're really doing vipassana. Then what happens is that you clarify the sense of self. The meditator, the meditating ego, becomes clarified in the two senses of the English word, to reiterate what I said before. It becomes crystal clear what part of it is idea and what part is body sensation. That's the components. And the subcomponents, the welling up and passing of those ideas and body sensations also become clear. And the sub-subcomponents, which are the vibrating atoms of those, that becomes clear. When that becomes clear in the first sense of the English word, then the sense of self becomes clear in the second sense. That which was opaque becomes transparent. That transparent self is in Buddhism called no-self. But it merely means a transparent self, a fluid self. The ideas and body sensations still arise, but there's so much light and so much relaxation there that they don't congeal into a rigid opaque object called a thing. They remain as a fluid and clear activity called personality. Does that make sense? Student 2 It's beginning to, this would be sort of, if that makes sense, an unmediated awareness with pure experience at that point. Yes. Which is all we ever have anyway. Okay? When you take away all the unconsciousness and the congealing, you're left with what was always there. Okay? So when we say observe, it's a misleading term, but we all use it. Okay? But ultimately you're not really observing. Observe means there's the object here and there's the meditator here. Real vipassana is an object arises and it's very, very clear and there's no tension in it. And ideas and body sensations that produce the sense of self arise and they're completely clear and there's no tension in it. Therefore, instead of object over here and observer over here, you have the object rising, passing, rising and passing as an effortless activity. The sense of observer rising, passing, rising, passing as an effortless activity. Those two activities becoming a single activity. Okay. Ego is an ambiguous word that means many things to many people, to many psychotherapists. Ego is a highly desirable quality because it means your ability to cope with the world and to integrate your inner experience. Well, ego in that sense is not gone. Not at all. In fact, ego in that sense gets stronger. Ego in the sense of so-and-so has an ego problem. Okay. Yeah. Ego in that sense is very much diminished. The vocabulary can be devastatingly ambiguous, human vocabulary. But I knew in which sense you meant ego. Now you feel your sense of self arising? I trust you. I'd note that one for a moment. Any other questions about the procedure so that you'll be able to do it? Yeah. Oh, okay. Right. I understand exactly your question. Since you brought it up, it's good to address. The question was, I pay attention to my breath. When I get distracted, I note that fact and I come back to my breath. Should I work that way? The answer is if you want to. But understand that there are actually two ways that labeling is done in the vipassana world. And I don't really think you are going to find this in any book. But if you go to retreats and you see how vipassana is being taught, there are really two very different ways that the labeling strategy is used. And I wouldn't say that one is right or one is wrong, but you shouldn't know the distinction between the ways and do one or the other. And I myself do teach just one of those ways, but not because I think it's the right one. It's just I don't want to confuse people too much. And given the general way that I like to teach vipassana, it works better with my style to do it as one of the ways. But let me tell you what the two ways are. In one way, one defines an object of meditation. Typically it's the breathing. And one is aware of that object of meditation and one may label, like a rising, falling. One may be labeling that object or may not be labeling that object. And then when a distraction arises, like a sound or another body sensation or a thought, the person labels and says thinking or hearing and then they come back intentionally to the breath. Now what they're doing is they're using that label as if to say, oh that was just a sound, now come back to the breath. It's sort of a cue to come back to a smaller object. Okay, that was a thought, but now we've come back to the breath. There's nothing wrong with working that way, but that's not the way that I just described the labeling process. That is another way of using the labeling. And an awful lot of people do it and it's fine. The distinction between that and the way I just described labeling is a subtle one, but I think you'll be able to get it. In the second way of working with labeling, you only label things inside the defined object of meditation, which of course could be as broad as everything. Your defined object of meditation could be the six senses. But when you label, the label is accompanied by an intense moment of concentration on the thing that you label. And you may or may not have a home base that you go to afterwards. The way I teach it, you don't have home base. Your job is to just label whatever comes up. And maybe if there's nothing coming up, you'll just naturally be drawn back to your breath. Well fine, but you're not making an intention to go there. That's the way I'm teaching it. So that you don't label unless you penetrate. Penetrate means that you get the awareness to soak into the thing you're labeling. So you don't casually say thought and then come back to breath. In the second way of working, if you say thought, your awareness skewers thought for a second or two. And it's just totally present. There's that establishment of mindfulness face to face with that intensely for the point that you label. And then you wait for the next phenomenon to come up and you penetrate that phenomenon with awareness as you label it. So that's a very different way of using labeling. In one, you are labeling primarily to just sort of remind yourself to come back to something. In the other, you are labeling to remind yourself to penetrate the thing you're labeling. In the first one, you're labeling to remind yourself to ignore the thing you're labeling and come back to some other object. Those are two very different ways of using labeling. And depending on whose retreat you're at, you'll be taught one or the other. But at least know that they're different. And not that one is good or one is bad. Personally, I like to do the latter. I like the idea that if you label, you penetrate. And if your defined object of meditation is the body sensations and you're getting distracted into thoughts, typically I would not tell people to say thinking. I would just tell them come right back to the body and start labeling again inside the body. If you want to label thinking, fine. But then define it as within the object of meditation and try to really let your awareness soak in and have tremendous clarity for a moment with respect to the thought as it's coming up. Does that make sense? Each time you sit down and do vipassana, you have a defined object of meditation. And that can be as narrow as the breath or as broad as all six senses. But you stay within that object of meditation during that sit, during that sitting. You typically do not change unless there is a very compelling reason to change. What would be a compelling reason? Your defined object of meditation is the breath and they start working with jackhammers across the street. And the sounds and the body sensations are so overwhelming you can't even detect your breath. Okay, then you make an intentional change. You say to yourself, in words to yourself, now I am shifting my object of meditation for this reason. So it's crystal clear. And now you have a new defined object of meditation. So I'm not saying that vipassana should be limited to body sensations. But the way I like to teach it is I like to take each aspect of experience, work with it individually, and then put it all together in one big package and work with all the senses at once. That's why I'm teaching you this now. I was wondering if this was part of the whole or whether this is a separate technique. It depends on what vipassana teacher you go to. If you were to study with the great enlightened master Buddhadasa in Thailand, he'd have you work 20 years just on the breath, penetrating more and more deeply and you'd go the entire path of liberation just with that one tiny aspect of experience, the breath. If you study in the Upakin Goenka tradition, they will give you, they'll start you out with the breath but then they'll broaden it very quickly to all body sensations. But they'll never go any broader than that. If you study with Upandita and the Mahasi lineage, the first day you sit down you'll be given the instruction, note every phenomenon that comes up. Okay, and that's it. It's like a one sentence instruction and then that will carry you for the rest of your life. But you have to work with all six senses at once. So it's going to depend on the teacher. And it's interesting, since so many vipassana teachers start you out with the breath and some keep you there for a long time. Some people that don't know much about vipassana think vipassana equals meditation on the breath. Personally, I would discourage you from limiting your object of meditation to being the breath. I know there's a lot of people that think, well I can't even stay focused on my breath, so maybe I better just work on that and not try these other things. But breath for me is primarily a developing of calm and concentration. For insight and purification I feel a somewhat larger object is usually more useful, like the body sensations or the thinking process or both. Shelly once had a really interesting experience. A group hired her, which was not a Buddhist group. They hired her to teach vipassana. They found, oh, you're a vipassana teacher. And after several classes they came to her and they were really upset. And they said, what are you trying to influence our students and playing games with trying to do weird things? We hired you to teach vipassana. We hired you to teach people to focus on their breath. What's all this stuff about watching their body sensations and their thoughts and all that? They had a completely different idea. For some reason they thought they were hiring her as a breath teacher. And she started to have them watch the impermanence of sensations and see that there's no self and everything. And they were a Hindu group and they were all freaked out. OK, any other questions? You make the defined object of your meditation your thoughts. You shine the flashlight not on the content of the thought, but what? Actually, again, I don't want to confuse people by giving you so many options. I'm going to just teach a certain way in this retreat. But some vipassana teachers, in fact, have you note the content. But in a simple way. Obviously, if you try to get too detailed with content, you get into journal writing. And you're not going to try a journal writing there. They would have you note whether it's typically it's most thoughts are either remembering, judging, planning, fantasizing, being confused, believing, wanting, things like that. Is making thought the object, is it useful in keeping yourself from getting carried away in it? It is. By the way, that would be noting the content of thought. That's not the way personally I like to observe thought, though. The answer to your question, if you don't note content, what do you note? Contour. How the thought gets more intense or less intense, how it speeds up or slows down. That's the contour of the thinking process. And that's what I'm going to be teaching you to note by and by. Does that make sense? Yeah. Like the contour is the changing wave form of it. So if you find your thoughts getting in the way of meditating, like you're just getting lost in them. You've got two possibilities. One is to yank yourself away from that each time it happens and bring your awareness back to the object. And that will eventually weaken the gravitational pull of the thinking. That's one option. A second option, if you know how, is to make the thought itself the object of meditation. And that will gradually clarify the thinking process. So if you yank yourself back, that will weaken the pull of the thoughts. If you observe the thinking process, it will make the thoughts transparent so that they're not in the way anymore. So that was a good question. Anything else specifically about the technique that I just gave you? Yes. You've covered this, but would you remind me if your meditation is on bodily sensations, and you suddenly experience a strong emotion, a flash of claustrophobia, I've got to get out of here. Then do you go and look where in the body that is taking place? Absolutely. If your defined object of meditation is body sensation and an emotion comes up, which is likely to happen, then you bring the qualities of mindfulness and equanimity to the body sensations that constitute the feeling half of that emotion. And you ignore the thinking half, if your defined object of meditation is body sensation. Of course, you could more broadly define your object of meditation to include also observing the feeling, the thinking half of the emotion. But it's much harder to observe thinking than it is to observe feeling. And it's much harder to observe the two at the same time than it is to observe either one individually. So no wonder human beings get so caught in their emotions. Of course, I just used the word observe again, didn't I? Okay, any other questions specifically about this procedure? It's pretty clear. Okay, good.

segments.text: I'd like to talk a little bit about a very useful technique in the vipassana tradition,
which is called labeling. As I mentioned, the basic principle in vipassana is to train,
to be able to maintain specific awareness with respect to the components of one's experience,
moment by moment. Like the proverbial pie, our experience can be cut up a lot of different ways,
and you can cut it into six pieces, but then each one of those pieces can be cut into sub-pieces,
and the pieces, sub-pieces can be more finely cut, because there are components, sub-components,
sub-sub-components in every experience. For example, if a person is having what in the English
language is referred to as an emotion, a negative emotion, let's say like fear or anger or irritation,
that experience has basically two components. One is that there are ideas, a sequence of ideas
erupt in the mind, and at the same time a sequence of sensations erupt in the body.
So the first level of cutting that experience or being aware of components would be to be able to
keep track what part of the experience is ideas, what part of the experience is body sensations.
So that would be keeping track of the components. But if you take a particular component, for example
the body sensations, those body sensations will be welling up in different parts of the body. So to
be aware of the locations as they change moment by moment would be to be aware of sub-components
of that experience. The body sensation is made up of a welling up in the knee and then a welling up
in the chest and then a welling up over the whole body and then maybe a welling up that goes to three
or four places and then a welling up that goes into the face, for example. So to know at any
given moment the body sensation involves face, chest, knee, whole body, is to know the sub-components.
To be aware that each welling up itself involves smaller fluctuations, each wave is made of sub-waves,
etc. To be able to trace that would be to know the sub-sub-components. Likewise with the thought,
to be able to be distinctly aware of each burst of thoughts, to know if thought is a component,
then each burst is a sub-component and each burst itself may speed up or slow down, may accelerate
or decelerate. To know those rates of acceleration and deceleration would be to know the sub-sub-components.
Having any motion is a rather large piece of experience. We can take a small piece of experience,
let's say the act of walking. To know the right foot is moving or the left foot is moving is to
know the components. To be aware of the lift, swing, and placing down of the right and left
foot is to know the sub-components. To be aware of the sequence of little jerks that constitute
the lifting, the sequence of little jerks and pulls that constitute the pushing forward of
the foot, the sequence of little jerks and pulls that constitutes the placing, the sequence of
impacts of the floor as it touches in different places, that is to know the sub-sub-components
of the act of walking. As we're sitting here in this room, components of our experience are hearing,
seeing, feeling in the body, and thinking. To know each time the eye shifts, however slightly, is to
know the sub-components of the seeing. To be able to detect the impact of sound as it wells up and
subsides, to experience it as changing levels, is to know the sub-component of the hearing
component. If a person were able to know the components, sub-components and sub-sub-components
of the entire experience of sitting here, well, we would say that that person's meditation had
covered the entire experience, and that would be indeed awesome. But yet, with practice, a person
can expect to be able to do this. So when I say be aware, it doesn't necessarily mean be thinking
about. It means be able to detect or have contact with or have sensitivity to. In order to develop
this kind of precision or clarity or specificity of awareness, there are various techniques that
have been developed within the Vipassana tradition, and one of them is labeling. When you do labeling,
you take some experience and you mentally or vocally label the components. For example, if
the experience is walking, you could label right, left, or you could label lifting, swinging,
placing. If the experience is breathing, each time you breathe out and you feel your abdomen or you
feel the breath at your nose, you could say to yourself, out. Each time you breathe in, you could
say in, or you could say rising, falling, as you feel the abdomen rise and fall. If you're having
an emotion, each time you're aware that the body is erupting, you could say feeling. Each time you're
aware that you had an idea, you could say to yourself, thinking. You'd be labeling the components
of the experience. Of course, the Vipassana awareness is not just components. It's to be
aware of components, subcomponents, sub-subcomponents. So the labels are only done with respect to the
really gross, large pieces of the pie, so to speak. It's completely impractical. Indeed,
it's impossible to make a description with labels of all the fine detail, all the subcomponents and
sub-subcomponents that you will be detecting. Your awareness will be very fine, very detailed,
detect a lot. But the label, the mental or the internally spoken or externally spoken word that
describes the component of experience, that is very simple and only deals with the large-scale
stuff. So as you say lifting and you lift your foot, you've just labeled the component lifting,
but your awareness should be able to detect many, many little movements involved with that lift.
But you don't try to label those. You don't try to say, you know, jerk, jerk, jerk, jerk, jerk,
or pulling, pulling, pulling. It's happening too quickly. Many things are happening simultaneously.
Many of the subtler things cannot be put into words. If you try to label too much detail,
you'll become frenetic. And definitely the purpose of the labeling is not to become frenetic. In
other words, if you find yourself feeling like a juggler that has too many balls and you're sort of,
you know, running to catch them, that means you're trying to label too much detail and cut down on the
detail and just label larger or more stately or slower aspects. I would say in general a person
makes a label every second or two or three or four seconds, something like that. If 10-15 seconds pass
and you haven't labeled something, then you're spacing out. Okay? But if you find yourself going
something like right, left, knee, you know, just like sort of out of breath trying to label all
this stuff, then you're labeling too quickly. So you'll find that there's a sort of pace there. As
I say, it's desirable that the awareness detect as much detail and as much quick material and
subtle material as possible. But the actual mental or spoken labels are just really big pieces. If
you think of the difference between the amount of information you get when you look at a picture
versus the amount of information you get when you look at the label of the picture, okay, you look
at the picture, there's an enormous amount of detail. The label is just something very, very
simple. And the same labels, landscape, still life, can refer to very different pictures. So you might
be noting where the sensation arises and you say knee, knee, knee. But each time you said knee,
there's a different shape, a different quality, a different intensity of sensation in the knee. But
you just simply label knee. By and large, the labels, the simpler the better. Because the
purpose of the labeling is not to describe what's going on. The purpose of the labeling is to point
your awareness to what's going on and to remind you to bring yourself back. The other purpose of
the labeling is because it's done in a very gentle and matter-of-fact voice, whether it's spoken
internally or externally. It's done, if I were to label body locations of my sensations, face, chest,
hands, very impersonal, very gentle, very matter-of-fact. So that labeling reminds you to be
gentle and open and matter-of-fact with the sensation or whatever phenomenon it is that
you're labeling. So the labeling does two things. It reminds you to focus your awareness and really
soak in to the thing that you're labeling. So really have a moment of great clarity with that.
And it reminds you to relax into that experience. Some people don't like labeling. If you don't like
it, don't do it. It's as simple as that. Just be aware of the components and sub-sub components.
The reason people don't like it is severalfold. One of the reasons people don't like it is
legitimate. Another reason that people don't like it is not legitimate. The legitimate reason why
people may not want to make those labels is it stimulates the thinking process. Some people find
that it's too agitating. They're trying to get calm and it militates against that. Although I
would say that what does happen with experience is that after a while you're just making the
labels and they don't stimulate the thinking. The labels themselves, believe me, are not an
agitation to the mind. The agitation of the mind is the turning, the churning of the mind. And once
you develop a skill at labeling, it doesn't agitate or make the mind churn. But at the beginnings,
because people are sort of trying to make those labels, it sometimes does agitate their mind in
general. Some vipassana teachers force you to keep on labeling despite that fact. And what you
discover is after a while the mind is not agitated by the act of labeling. But other vipassana
teachers say, well, if a person doesn't like doing it because it agitates their mind, then why require
that they do it since it's after all just a stratagem, it's just a crutch to develop the
mindfulness. If you can have the mindfulness without the labels, then well and good. But
there's another reason why people don't do the labeling, which is not legitimate. And that is
it's hard work. It's much easier to sit there and be spacey than to force yourself to describe what's
going on, either mentally or vocally. And that's no excuse for not doing it, okay? Because it's
like if you don't lift heavy weights, if there's not some challenge, then the muscles will never
develop. And there is a certain aspect of work involved. Of course, you don't want to lift weights
that are too heavy, because you could pull a muscle. Labeling can be done either mentally or
vocally. For vocal labeling, you can go outside, you can go to your room, because obviously you
don't want to be the only one in the room talking while everybody else is in silence, unless you
want to observe the sensations that go with the intense self-consciousness of knowing that
everybody thinks that you're an SOB, okay? Which could in and of itself be a deeply enlightening
meditation. If you were really doing that, I wouldn't mind if you labeled in the room, okay?
But it's pretty hard to do that. As I say, the advantage of having our own private rooms, well,
on a retreat we call them meditation cells, not rooms, okay? That's the old word from the Middle
Ages. The monks, you know, they are in their cells. So you have your own private cells for meditation,
is you can go and do the vocal labeling. People resist the mental labeling, they resist the vocal
labeling even more. Then don't come to me and complain that your mind is wandering, okay? Or
that you're having difficulty concentrating, because the first thing I'm going to ask you is,
have you tried going to your room and vocal labeling? Because when we get caught up in our
own thinking process, which of course is the most common bete noire, the monster that bothers people
at the beginning of their meditation, it means we're yanked into a kind of valley of subjectivity.
Vocally labeling, saying the words out loud in a crisp, clear way, is a very objective biofeedback
procedure. It's feedback on what's going on inside of you. And you can't be grossly spaced out and
be listening for your own voice every second or two seconds. You can't be spaced out for more
than a second or two if you're listening to your own voice. If you're mentally labeling,
it's a little easier to space out. If you don't label and try to do it with direct awareness,
that's the most peaceful, but that is also the one that is the easiest to get spaced out with.
So you can make choices whether you want to have just direct mindfulness or use mental labels to
prompt your mindfulness or use vocal labeling. You can think of it as gears of a car. If you're going
up a hill, go into first gear. Go to your meditation cell and vocally label. If you're
on the highway and there's no traffic, cruise control. You can just be with direct awareness

that there are actually two ways that labeling is done in the vipassana world. And I don't
really think you are going to find this in any book. But if you go to retreats and you
see how vipassana is being taught, there are really two very different ways that the labeling
strategy is used. And I wouldn't say that one is right or one is wrong, but you shouldn't
know the distinction between the ways and do one or the other. And I myself do teach
just one of those ways, but not because I think it's the right one. It's just I don't
want to confuse people too much. And given the general way that I like to teach vipassana,
it works better with my style to do it as one of the ways. But let me tell you what
the two ways are. In one way, one defines an object of meditation. Typically it's the
breathing. And one is aware of that object of meditation and one may label, like a rising,
falling. One may be labeling that object or may not be labeling that object. And then
when a distraction arises, like a sound or another body sensation or a thought, the person
labels and says thinking or hearing and then they come back intentionally to the breath.
Now what they're doing is they're using that label as if to say, oh that was just
a sound, now come back to the breath. It's sort of a cue to come back to a smaller object.
Okay, that was a thought, but now we've come back to the breath. There's nothing
wrong with working that way, but that's not the way that I just described the labeling
process. That is another way of using the labeling. And an awful lot of people do it
and it's fine. The distinction between that and the way I just described labeling is a
subtle one, but I think you'll be able to get it. In the second way of working with
labeling, you only label things inside the defined object of meditation, which of course
could be as broad as everything. Your defined object of meditation could be the six senses.
But when you label, the label is accompanied by an intense moment of concentration on the
thing that you label. And you may or may not have a home base that you go to afterwards.
The way I teach it, you don't have home base. Your job is to just label whatever
comes up. And maybe if there's nothing coming up, you'll just naturally be drawn back
to your breath. Well fine, but you're not making an intention to go there. That's
the way I'm teaching it. So that you don't label unless you penetrate. Penetrate means
that you get the awareness to soak into the thing you're labeling. So you don't casually
say thought and then come back to breath. In the second way of working, if you say thought,
your awareness skewers thought for a second or two. And it's just totally present. There's
that establishment of mindfulness face to face with that intensely for the point that
you label. And then you wait for the next phenomenon to come up and you penetrate that
phenomenon with awareness as you label it. So that's a very different way of using
labeling. In one, you are labeling primarily to just sort of remind yourself to come back
to something. In the other, you are labeling to remind yourself to penetrate the thing
you're labeling. In the first one, you're labeling to remind yourself to ignore the
thing you're labeling and come back to some other object. Those are two very different
ways of using labeling. And depending on whose retreat you're at, you'll be taught one or
the other. But at least know that they're different. And not that one is good or one
is bad. Personally, I like to do the latter. I like the idea that if you label, you penetrate.
And if your defined object of meditation is the body sensations and you're getting distracted
into thoughts, typically I would not tell people to say thinking. I would just tell
them come right back to the body and start labeling again inside the body. If you want
to label thinking, fine. But then define it as within the object of meditation and try
to really let your awareness soak in and have tremendous clarity for a moment with respect
to the thought as it's coming up. Does that make sense? Each time you sit down and do
vipassana, you have a defined object of meditation. And that can be as narrow as the breath or
as broad as all six senses. But you stay within that object of meditation during that sit,
during that sitting. You typically do not change unless there is a very compelling reason
to change. What would be a compelling reason? Your defined object of meditation is the breath
and they start working with jackhammers across the street. And the sounds and the body sensations
are so overwhelming you can't even detect your breath. Okay, then you make an intentional
change. You say to yourself, in words to yourself, now I am shifting my object of meditation
for this reason. So it's crystal clear. And now you have a new defined object of meditation.
So I'm not saying that vipassana should be limited to body sensations. But the way I
like to teach it is I like to take each aspect of experience, work with it individually,
and then put it all together in one big package and work with all the senses at once. That's
why I'm teaching you this now.
I was wondering if this was part of the whole or whether this is a separate technique.
It depends on what vipassana teacher you go to. If you were to study with the great enlightened
master Buddhadasa in Thailand, he'd have you work 20 years just on the breath, penetrating
more and more deeply and you'd go the entire path of liberation just with that one tiny
aspect of experience, the breath. If you study in the Upakin Goenka tradition, they will
give you, they'll start you out with the breath but then they'll broaden it very quickly to
all body sensations. But they'll never go any broader than that. If you study with Upandita
and the Mahasi lineage, the first day you sit down you'll be given the instruction,
note every phenomenon that comes up. Okay, and that's it. It's like a one sentence instruction
and then that will carry you for the rest of your life. But you have to work with all
six senses at once. So it's going to depend on the teacher. And it's interesting, since
so many vipassana teachers start you out with the breath and some keep you there for a long
time. Some people that don't know much about vipassana think vipassana equals meditation
on the breath. Personally, I would discourage you from limiting your object of meditation
to being the breath. I know there's a lot of people that think, well I can't even stay
focused on my breath, so maybe I better just work on that and not try these other things.
But breath for me is primarily a developing of calm and concentration. For insight and
purification I feel a somewhat larger object is usually more useful, like the body sensations
or the thinking process or both. Shelly once had a really interesting experience. A group

a Hindu group and they were all freaked out.

You've got two possibilities. One is to yank yourself away from that each time it happens

A second option, if you know how, is to make the thought itself the object of meditation.

You've covered this, but would you remind me if your meditation is on bodily sensations,

Absolutely. If your defined object of meditation is body sensation and an emotion comes up,

the thinking half, if your defined object of meditation is body sensation.
Of course, you could more broadly define your object of meditation to include also observing
